contextId.information: This phrase compares the unfaithful people to prostitutes. AT: "by doing that, they seek advice from the spirits rather than from me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so as to prostitute themselves with them

contextId.information: This phrase compares having sex with a woman during her menstrual period to removing the cover off of something that should remain hidden. The fact that this was a shameful thing to do can be stated clearly. AT: "he has done a shameful thing by by uncovering the flow of her blood"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: he has uncovered the flow of her blood, the source of her blood

contextId.information: This phrase describes the land as a vomiting person who needs to reject bad food. Instead of rejecting bad food, the land rejects the people and removes them. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:lev:18:24|18:25]]. AT: "the land to which I am bringing you will not reject you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: the land into which I am bringing you to live will not vomit you up

contextId.information: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: make himself unclean

contextId.information: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: while he is unclean

contextId.information: A priest no longer being able to serve Yahweh is spoken of as if that person had been cut off from Yahweh's presence, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. This can be translated in active form. AT: "that person will no longer be able to serve as a priest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: that person must be cut off from before me

contextId.information: Something that Yahweh has said is unfit to touch or eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Whoever touches anything unclean

contextId.information: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the priest ... will be unclean

contextId.information: "the priest will then be considered clean." A person who is acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he will then be clean

contextId.information: Sin is spoken of as if it were an object that people can carry. Possible meanings are 1) they would be responsible for the sin and so become guilty. AT: "they would be guilty for the sin that they committed" or 2) the word "sin" is a metonym for punishment for the sin that they committed. AT: "they would receive the punishment because they are guilty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: cause themselves to carry the sin that would make them guilty

contextId.information: The Lord's pleasure with the aroma represents his pleasure with the person who burns the offering. AT: "and Yahweh will be pleased with you" or "that pleases the Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and producing a sweet aroma for Yahweh

contextId.information: Being excluded is spoken of as being cut off. See how you translated this idea in [[:en:bible:notes:lev:07:19|7:20]]. AT: "must be excluded from his people" or "you must separate that person from his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: must be cut off from his people

contextId.information: Suffering for sin is spoken of if a person were to carry his guilt. AT: "must suffer for his sin" or "must be punished (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: must carry his own guilt

contextId.information: Walking among them represents living with them. AT: "I will live with you"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will walk among you

contextId.information: God speaks of their slavery as if they had to wear a yoke that animals wear in order to do hard work. Breaking the bars of the yoke represents setting them free. AT: "I have set you free from the hard labor they made you do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have broken the bars of your yoke

contextId.information: Here "terror" represents the things that will cause them to be terrified. AT: "I will send disasters that will terrify you"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will inflict terror on you

contextId.information: Using force to cause them not to be proud is spoken of as if he were to break their pride. AT: "I will punish you and so end the pride that you feel about your power" and "I will punish you so that you will no longer be proud of your power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will break your pride in your power

contextId.information: Working very hard is spoken of as if they were to use all their strength until they had no more strength. The phrase "for nothing" means that they would get nothing from working so hard.  AT: "You will work very hard in vain" or "You will work very hard, but you will not receive anything good from working so hard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Your strength will be used up for nothing

contextId.information: Walking represents behavior. Walking against God represents opposing him or rebelling against him. AT: "rebel against me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walk against me

contextId.information: Yahweh causing disasters to happen to the Israelites is spoken of as if he would strike them with blows or hit them. AT: "I will cause seven times as many disasters to come against you" or "I will punish you seven times more severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will bring seven times more blows on you

contextId.information: Stealing represents attacking or attacking and dragging them away. AT: "which will attack your children" or "which will drag your children away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: which will steal your children

contextId.information: Accepting his correction represents responding rightly to it. In this case responding rightly to it is choosing to obey him. AT: "you still do not listen to my correction" or "you still do not obey me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you still do not accept my correction

contextId.information: Walking represents behavior. Walking in opposition to them  means opposing them or fighting against them. AT: "I also will oppose you" or "I also will fight against you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will also walk in opposition to you

contextId.information: Destroying the food that people have stored or stopping people from being able to get it is spoken of as cutting off the supply of food. AT: "When I destroy the food you have stored" or "When I  stop you from being able to get food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When I cut off your food supply

contextId.information: Walking represents behavior. Walking against someone represents opposing him or fighting against him. AT: "to oppose me" or "to fight against me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to walk against me

contextId.information: God speaks of idols not being alive as if they had been alive and then died. AT: "your lifeless idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the corpses of your idols

contextId.information: Normally the Lord's pleasure with the aroma represents his pleasure with those who burn the offering. But in this case, people would burn offerings, but God would not be pleased with them. AT: "You will burn offerings, but I will not be pleased with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will not be pleased with the aroma of your offerings

contextId.information: Sending fear into their hearts represents making them afraid. AT: "I will make you terribly afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will send fear into your hearts

contextId.information: If Yahweh will not accept a certain animal as an offering, the animal is spoken of as if it were physically dirty. It may be unclean because it is a certain kind of animal or because it has a defect. AT: "is in fact one that Yahweh will not accept" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is in fact unclean, so that Yahweh will not accept it

contextId.information: "Stand" represents "remain" or "remain the same." AT: "its value will remain the same" or "its value will be the full amount" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the valuation of it will stand
